prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: CO(2-1) flux derived from JCMT observations (21" resolution) by Petitpas & Wilson (2003) Using a standard Jy/K for the JCMT of 26, the integrated CO(2-1) flux for a 21" beam would be 3146 Jy km/s For an angular resolution of 1", we deduce the goal sensitivity for a 5 sigma detection, with a 10km/s spectral binning of: 3146Jy km/s /500 km/s *10 km/s *(1"/21")**2 /5 sigma = 28 mJy For the width of the line (500km/s) and the fact that we want to smooth the spectra to 10km/s, we will be using the coarsest FDM mode for the spw with emissions lines and TDM for the other spw, to maximize continuum sensitivity.One of the spw is set to detect CS(5-4). We only need to recover spatial scales that can be compared with the other line transitions, which will be more compact, so we have used a conservative estimate of ~10" which does not require additional ACA observations.

CO(3-2) flux derived from APEX observations (18" resolution) by Pinol-Ferrer et al (2011). Using a standard Jy/K for APEX, the integrated CO(3-2) flux for a 18" beam would be 4168 Jy km/s For an angular resolution of 1", we deduce the goal sensitivity for a 5 sigma detection, with a 10km/s spectral binning of: 4168Jy km/s /500 km/s *10 km/s *(1"/18")**2 /5 sigma = 5 mJy For the width of the line (500km/s) and the fact that we want to smooth the spectra to 10km/s, we will be using the coarsest FDM mode for the spw with emissions lines and TDM for the other spw, to maximize continuum sensitivity. We only need to recover spatial scales that can be compared with the other line transitions, which will be more compact, so we have used a conservative estimate of ~7" which does not require additional ACA observations.

CO(4-3) flux derived from CO(2-1) JCMT observations (21" resolution) by Petitpas & Wilson (2003), assuming a CO(4-3)/CO(2-1)~0.5 intensity ratio. Using a standard Jy/K for JCMT of 26, the integrated CO(4-3) flux for a 21" beam would be 4651 Jy km/s For an angular resolution of 1", we deduce the goal sensitivity for a 5 sigma detection, with a 10km/s spectral binning of: 4651Jy km/s /500 km/s *10 km/s *(1"/21")**2 /5 sigma = 6 mJy For the width of the line (500km/s) and the fact that we want to smooth the spectra to 10km/s, we will be using the coarsest FDM mode for the spw with emissions lines and TDM for the other spw, to maximize continuum sensitivity. We only need to recover spatial scales that can be compared with the other line transitions, which will be more compact, so we have used a conservative estimate of ~5" which does not require additional ACA observations.

CO(2-1) flux derived from SEST observations (21" resolution) by Bajaja et al (1995) Using a standard Jy/K for the SEST of 26, the integrated CO(2-1) flux for a 21" beam would be 2158 Jy km/s For an angular resolution of 1", we deduce the goal sensitivity for a 5 sigma detection, with a 5km/s spectral binning of: 2158Jy km/s /200 km/s *5 km/s *(1"/21")**2 /5 sigma = 25 mJy For the width of the line (200km/s) and the fact that we want to smooth the spectra to 5km/s, we will be using the coarsest FDM mode for the spw with emissions lines and TDM for the other spw, to maximize continuum sensitivity. One of the spw is set to detect CS(5-4). We only need to recover spatial scales that can be compared with the other line transitions, which will be more compact, so we have used a conservative estimate of ~10" which does not require additional ACA observations.

CO(3-2) flux derived from CO(2-1) SEST observations (21" resolution) by Bajaja et al (1995), assuming a CO(3-2)/CO(2-1)~0.8 intensity ratio. Using a standard Jy/K for SEST of 26, the integrated CO(3-2) flux for a 21" beam would be 3884 Jy km/s For an angular resolution of 1", we deduce the goal sensitivity for a 5 sigma detection, with a 5km/s spectral binning of: 3884Jy km/s /200 km/s *5 km/s *(1"/21")**2 /5 sigma = 44 mJy For the width of the line (200km/s) and the fact that we want to smooth the spectra to 5km/s, we will be using the coarsest FDM mode for the spw with emissions lines and TDM for the other spw, to maximize continuum sensitivity. We only need to recover spatial scales that can be compared with the other line transitions, which will be more compact, so we have used a conservative estimate of ~7" which does not require additional ACA observations.

CO(4-3) flux derived from CO(2-1) SEST observations (21" resolution) by Bajaja et al (1995), assuming a CO(4-3)/CO(2-1)~0.5 intensity ratio. Using a standard Jy/K for JCMT of 26, the integrated CO(4-3) flux for a 21" beam would be 4651 Jy km/s For an angular resolution of 1", we deduce the goal sensitivity for a 5 sigma detection, with a 5km/s spectral binning of: 4651Jy km/s /200 km/s *5 km/s *(1"/21")**2 /5 sigma = 49 mJy For the width of the line (200km/s) and the fact that we want to smooth the spectra to 5km/s, we will be using the coarsest FDM mode for the spw with emissions lines and TDM for the other spw, to maximize continuum sensitivity. We only need to recover spatial scales that can be compared with the other line transitions, which will be more compact, so we have used a conservative estimate of ~5" which does not require additional ACA observations.

CO(2-1) flux derived from JCMT observations (21" resolution) by Rigopoulou et al (1997) Using a standard Jy/K for the JCMT of 26, the integrated CO(2-1) flux for a 21" beam would be 108.2 Jy km/s For an angular resolution of 1", we deduce the goal sensitivity for a 5 sigma detection, with a 10km/s spectral binning of: 3146Jy km/s /260 km/s *10 km/s *(1"/21")**2 /5 sigma = 1.5 mJy For the width of the line (260km/s) and the fact that we want to smooth the spectra to 10km/s, we will be using the coarsest FDM mode for the spw with emissions lines and TDM for the other spw, to maximize continuum sensitivity.One of the spw is set to detect CS(5-4). We only need to recover spatial scales that can be compared with the other line transitions, which will be more compact, so we have used a conservative estimate of ~10" which does not require additional ACA observations.

CO(3-2) flux derived from CO(2-1) JCMT observations (21" resolution) by Rigopoulou et al (1997), assuming a CO(3-2)/CO(2-1)~0.8 intensity ratio. Using a standard Jy/K for JCMT of 26, the integrated CO(3-2) flux for a 21" beam would be 195 Jy km/s For an angular resolution of 1", we deduce the goal sensitivity for a 5 sigma detection, with a 10km/s spectral binning of: 195Jy km/s /260 km/s *10 km/s *(1"/21")**2 /5 sigma = 3.5 mJy For the width of the line (260km/s) and the fact that we want to smooth the spectra to 10km/s, we will be using the coarsest FDM mode for the spw with emissions lines and TDM for the other spw, to maximize continuum sensitivity. We only need to recover spatial scales that can be compared with the other line transitions, which will be more compact, so we have used a conservative estimate of ~7" which does not require additional ACA observations.

CO(4-3) flux derived from CO(2-1) JCMT observations (21" resolution) by Rigopoulou et al (1997), assuming a CO(4-3)/CO(2-1)~0.5 intensity ratio. Using a standard Jy/K for JCMT of 26, the integrated CO(4-3) flux for a 21" beam would be 217 Jy km/s For an angular resolution of 1", we deduce the goal sensitivity for a 5 sigma detection, with a 10km/s spectral binning of: 260Jy km/s /260 km/s *10 km/s *(1"/21")**2 /5 sigma = 4 mJy For the width of the line (260km/s) and the fact that we want to smooth the spectra to 10km/s, we will be using the coarsest FDM mode for the spw with emissions lines and TDM for the other spw, to maximize continuum sensitivity. We only need to recover spatial scales that can be compared with the other line transitions, which will be more compact, so we have used a conservative estimate of ~5" which does not require additional ACA observations.

CO(2-1) flux derived from SMTO CO(3-2) observations (21" resolution) by Mao et al (2010) assuming an intensity ratio of 0.8 for the beam-matched CO(3-2)/CO(2-1) ratio. Using a standard Jy/K for the SMTO of 59, the integrated CO(2-1) flux for a 21" beam would be 420 Jy km/s For an angular resolution of 1", we deduce the goal sensitivity for a 5 sigma detection, with a 5km/s spectral binning of: 420Jy km/s /100 km/s *5 km/s *(1"/21")**2 /5 sigma = 10 mJy For the width of the line (100km/s) and the fact that we want to smooth the spectra to 5km/s, we will be using the coarsest FDM mode for the spw with emissions lines and TDM for the other spw, to maximize continuum sensitivity.One of the spw is set to detect CS(5-4). We only need to recover spatial scales that can be compared with the other line transitions, which will be more compact, so we have used a conservative estimate of ~10" which does not require additional ACA observations.

CO(3-2) flux derived from SMTO observations (21" resolution) by Mao et al (2010). Using a standard Jy/K for SMTO of 58.6, the integrated CO(3-2) flux for a 21" beam would be 756 Jy km/s For an angular resolution of 1", we deduce the goal sensitivity for a 5 sigma detection, with a 5km/s spectral binning of: 756Jy km/s /100 km/s *5 km/s *(1"/21")**2 /5 sigma = 17 mJy For the width of the line (100km/s) and the fact that we want to smooth the spectra to 5km/s, we will be using the coarsest FDM mode for the spw with emissions lines and TDM for the other spw, to maximize continuum sensitivity. We only need to recover spatial scales that can be compared with the other line transitions, which will be more compact, so we have used a conservative estimate of ~7" which does not require additional ACA observations.

CO(4-3) flux derived from CO(3-2) SMTO observations (21" resolution) by Mao et al (2010), assuming a CO(4-3)/CO(3-2)~0.6 intensity ratio. Using a standard Jy/K for SMTO of 59, the integrated CO(4-3) flux for a 21" beam would be 844 Jy km/s For an angular resolution of 1", we deduce the goal sensitivity for a 5 sigma detection, with a 5km/s spectral binning of: 844Jy km/s /100 km/s *5 km/s *(1"/21")**2 /5 sigma = 19 mJy For the width of the line (100km/s) and the fact that we want to smooth the spectra to 5km/s, we will be using the coarsest FDM mode for the spw with emissions lines and TDM for the other spw, to maximize continuum sensitivity. We only need to recover spatial scales that can be compared with the other line transitions, which will be more compact, so we have used a conservative estimate of ~5" which does not require additional ACA observations.

CO(2-1) flux derived from SMTO CO(3-2) observations (21" resolution) by Mao et al (2010) assuming an intensity ratio of 0.8 for the beam-matched CO(3-2)/CO(2-1) ratio. Using a standard Jy/K for the SMTO of 59, the integrated CO(2-1) flux for a 21" beam would be 219 Jy km/s For an angular resolution of 1", we deduce the goal sensitivity for a 5 sigma detection, with a 5km/s spectral binning of: 219Jy km/s /60 km/s *5 km/s *(1"/21")**2 /5 sigma = 8 mJy For the width of the line (60km/s) and the fact that we want to smooth the spectra to 5km/s, we will be using the coarsest FDM mode for the spw with emissions lines and TDM for the other spw, to maximize continuum sensitivity.One of the spw is set to detect CS(5-4). We only need to recover spatial scales that can be compared with the other line transitions, which will be more compact, so we have used a conservative estimate of ~10" which does not require additional ACA observations.

CO(3-2) flux derived from SMTO observations (21" resolution) by Mao et al (2010). Using a standard Jy/K for SMTO of 58.6, the integrated CO(3-2) flux for a 21" beam would be 393 Jy km/s For an angular resolution of 1", we deduce the goal sensitivity for a 5 sigma detection, with a 5km/s spectral binning of: 393Jy km/s /60 km/s *5 km/s *(1"/21")**2 /5 sigma = 15 mJy For the width of the line (60km/s) and the fact that we want to smooth the spectra to 5km/s, we will be using the coarsest FDM mode for the spw with emissions lines and TDM for the other spw, to maximize continuum sensitivity. We only need to recover spatial scales that can be compared with the other line transitions, which will be more compact, so we have used a conservative estimate of ~7" which does not require additional ACA observations.

CO(4-3) flux derived from CO(3-2) SMTO observations (21" resolution) by Mao et al (2010), assuming a CO(4-3)/CO(3-2)~0.6 intensity ratio. Using a standard Jy/K for SMTO of 59, the integrated CO(4-3) flux for a 21" beam would be 789 Jy km/s For an angular resolution of 1", we deduce the goal sensitivity for a 5 sigma detection, with a 5km/s spectral binning of: 789Jy km/s /60 km/s *5 km/s *(1"/21")**2 /5 sigma = 30 mJy For the width of the line (60km/s) and the fact that we want to smooth the spectra to 5km/s, we will be using the coarsest FDM mode for the spw with emissions lines and TDM for the other spw, to maximize continuum sensitivity. We only need to recover spatial scales that can be compared with the other line transitions, which will be more compact, so we have used a conservative estimate of ~5" which does not require additional ACA observations.

CO(2-1) flux derived from SMA observations (~2-5" resolution) by the BODEGA consortium (D. Espada, private comminucation) Using those data the integrated CO(2-1) flux for that beam would be 42000 Jy km/s For an angular resolution of 1", we deduce the goal sensitivity for a 5 sigma detection, with a 5km/s spectral binning of: 42000Jy km/s /120 km/s *5 km/s *(1"/4")**2 /5 sigma = 20 mJy For the width of the line (120km/s) and the fact that we want to smooth the spectra to 5km/s, we will be using the coarsest FDM mode for the spw with emissions lines and TDM for the other spw, to maximize continuum sensitivity.One of the spw is set to detect CS(5-4). We only need to recover spatial scales that can be compared with the other line transitions, which will be more compact, so we have used a conservative estimate of ~10" which does not require additional ACA observations.

CO(3-2) flux derived from SMA CO(2-1) observations (~2-5" resolution) by the BODEGA consortium (D. Espada, private comminucation), assuming a CO(3-2)/CO(2-1)~0.8 intensity ratio Using those data the integrated CO(3-2) flux for that beam would be 33600 Jy km/s For an angular resolution of 1", we deduce the goal sensitivity for a 5 sigma detection, with a 5km/s spectral binning of: 33600Jy km/s /120 km/s *5 km/s *(1"/4")**2 /5 sigma = 18 mJy For the width of the line (120km/s) and the fact that we want to smooth the spectra to 5km/s, we will be using the coarsest FDM mode for the spw with emissions lines and TDM for the other spw, to maximize continuum sensitivity.One of the spw is set to detect CS(5-4). We only need to recover spatial scales that can be compared with the other line transitions, which will be more compact, so we have used a conservative estimate of ~10" which does not require additional ACA observations.

CO(4-3) flux derived from SMA CO(2-1) observations (~2-5" resolution) by the BODEGA consortium (D. Espada, private comminucation), assuming a CO(4-3)/CO(2-1)~0.5 intensity ratio Using those data the integrated CO(3-2) flux for that beam would be 21000 Jy km/s For an angular resolution of 1", we deduce the goal sensitivity for a 5 sigma detection, with a 5km/s spectral binning of: 21000Jy km/s /120 km/s *5 km/s *(1"/4")**2 /5 sigma = 12.5 mJy For the width of the line (120km/s) and the fact that we want to smooth the spectra to 5km/s, we will be using the coarsest FDM mode for the spw with emissions lines and TDM for the other spw, to maximize continuum sensitivity.One of the spw is set to detect CS(5-4). We only need to recover spatial scales that can be compared with the other line transitions, which will be more compact, so we have used a conservative estimate of ~10" which does not require additional ACA observations.

CO(2-1) flux derived from CO(1-0) SEST observations (45" resolution) by Aalto et al (1995), assuming a CO(2-1)/CO(1-0)~1 intensity ratio Using a standard Jy/K for the SEST of 26, the integrated CO(2-1) flux for a 21" beam would be 284 Jy km/s For an angular resolution of 1", we deduce the goal sensitivity for a 5 sigma detection, with a 10km/s spectral binning of: 284Jy km/s /300 km/s *10 km/s *(1"/21")**2 /5 sigma = 4 mJy For the width of the line (300km/s) and the fact that we want to smooth the spectra to 10km/s, we will be using the coarsest FDM mode for the spw with emissions lines and TDM for the other spw, to maximize continuum sensitivity. One of the spw is set to detect CS(5-4). We only need to recover spatial scales that can be compared with the other line transitions, which will be more compact, so we have used a conservative estimate of ~10" which does not require additional ACA observations.

CO(3-2) flux derived from SEST CO(2-1) observations (21" resolution) by Aalto et al (1995), assuming a CO(3-2)/CO(2-1)~0.8 intensity ratio. Using a standard Jy/K for SEST of 26, the integrated CO(3-2) flux for a 21" beam would be 510 Jy km/s For an angular resolution of 1", we deduce the goal sensitivity for a 5 sigma detection, with a 10km/s spectral binning of: 510Jy km/s /300 km/s *10km/s *(1"/21")**2 /5 sigma = 8 mJy For the width of the line (300km/s) and the fact that we want to smooth the spectra to 10km/s, we will be using the coarsest FDM mode for the spw with emissions lines and TDM for the other spw, to maximize continuum sensitivity. We only need to recover spatial scales that can be compared with the other line transitions, which will be more compact, so we have used a conservative estimate of ~7" which does not require additional ACA observations.

CO(4-3) flux derived from CO(2-1) SEST observations (21" resolution) by Aalto et al (1995), assuming a CO(4-3)/CO(2-1)~0.5 intensity ratio. Using a standard Jy/K for SEST of 26, the integrated CO(4-3) flux for a 21" beam would be 569 Jy km/s For an angular resolution of 1", we deduce the goal sensitivity for a 5 sigma detection, with a 10km/s spectral binning of: 569Jy km/s /300 km/s *10 km/s *(1"/21")**2 /5 sigma = 9 mJy For the width of the line (300km/s) and the fact that we want to smooth the spectra to 10km/s, we will be using the coarsest FDM mode for the spw with emissions lines and TDM for the other spw, to maximize continuum sensitivity. We only need to recover spatial scales that can be compared with the other line transitions, which will be more compact, so we have used a conservative estimate of ~5" which does not require additional ACA observations.

CO(2-1) flux derived from SEST observations (21" resolution) by Albrecht et al (2007) Using a standard Jy/K for the SEST of 26, the integrated CO(2-1) flux for a 21" beam would be 289 Jy km/s For an angular resolution of 1", we deduce the goal sensitivity for a 5 sigma detection, with a 10km/s spectral binning of: 2158Jy km/s /500 km/s *10 km/s *(1"/21")**2 /5 sigma = 3 mJy For the width of the line (500km/s) and the fact that we want to smooth the spectra to 10km/s, we will be using the coarsest FDM mode for the spw with emissions lines and TDM for the other spw, to maximize continuum sensitivity. One of the spw is set to detect CS(5-4). We only need to recover spatial scales that can be compared with the other line transitions, which will be more compact, so we have used a conservative estimate of ~10" which does not require additional ACA observations.

CO(3-2) flux derived from SEST CO(2-1) observations (21" resolution) by Albrecht et al (2007), assuming a CO(3-2)/CO(2-1)~0.8 intensity ratio. Using a standard Jy/K for SEST of 26, the integrated CO(3-2) flux for a 21" beam would be 520 Jy km/s For an angular resolution of 1", we deduce the goal sensitivity for a 5 sigma detection, with a 10km/s spectral binning of: 756Jy km/s /500 km/s *10 km/s *(1"/21")**2 /5 sigma = 5 mJy For the width of the line (500km/s) and the fact that we want to smooth the spectra to 10km/s, we will be using the coarsest FDM mode for the spw with emissions lines and TDM for the other spw, to maximize continuum sensitivity. We only need to recover spatial scales that can be compared with the other line transitions, which will be more compact, so we have used a conservative estimate of ~7" which does not require additional ACA observations.

CO(4-3) flux derived from CO(2-1) SEST observations (21" resolution) by Albrecht et al (2007), assuming a CO(4-3)/CO(2-1)~0.5 intensity ratio. Using a standard Jy/K for SEST of 26, the integrated CO(4-3) flux for a 21" beam would be 580 Jy km/s For an angular resolution of 1", we deduce the goal sensitivity for a 5 sigma detection, with a 10km/s spectral binning of: 580Jy km/s /500 km/s *10 km/s *(1"/21")**2 /5 sigma = 5.5 mJy For the width of the line (500km/s) and the fact that we want to smooth the spectra to 10km/s, we will be using the coarsest FDM mode for the spw with emissions lines and TDM for the other spw, to maximize continuum sensitivity. We only need to recover spatial scales that can be compared with the other line transitions, which will be more compact, so we have used a conservative estimate of ~5" which does not require additional ACA observations.

CO(2-1) flux derived from CO(1-0) SEST observations (45" resolution) by Elfhag et al (1996), assuming a CO(2-1)/CO(1-0)~1 intensity ratio Using a standard Jy/K for the SEST of 26, the integrated CO(2-1) flux for a 21" beam would be 104 Jy km/s For an angular resolution of 1", we deduce the goal sensitivity for a 5 sigma detection, with a 5km/s spectral binning of: 104Jy km/s /150 km/s *5 km/s *(1"/21")**2 /5 sigma = 2 mJy For the width of the line (150km/s) and the fact that we want to smooth the spectra to 5km/s, we will be using the coarsest FDM mode for the spw with emissions lines and TDM for the other spw, to maximize continuum sensitivity. One of the spw is set to detect CS(5-4). We only need to recover spatial scales that can be compared with the other line transitions, which will be more compact, so we have used a conservative estimate of ~10" which does not require additional ACA observations.

CO(3-2) flux derived from CO(2-1) SEST observations (21" resolution) by Elfhag et al (1996), assuming a CO(3-2)/CO(2-1) ~ 0.8 intensity ratio. Using a standard Jy/K for SEST of 26, the integrated CO(3-2) flux for a 21" beam would be 187 Jy km/s For an angular resolution of 1", we deduce the goal sensitivity for a 5 sigma detection, with a 5km/s spectral binning of: 187Jy km/s /150 km/s *5 km/s *(1"/21")**2 /5 sigma = 3 mJy For the width of the line (150km/s) and the fact that we want to smooth the spectra to 5km/s, we will be using the coarsest FDM mode for the spw with emissions lines and TDM for the other spw, to maximize continuum sensitivity. We only need to recover spatial scales that can be compared with the other line transitions, which will be more compact, so we have used a conservative estimate of ~7" which does not require additional ACA observations.

CO(4-3) flux derived from CO(2-1) SEST observations (21" resolution) by Elfhag et al (1996), assuming a CO(4-3)/CO(2-1)~0.5 intensity ratio. Using a standard Jy/K for SEST of 26, the integrated CO(4-3) flux for a 21" beam would be 209 Jy km/s For an angular resolution of 1", we deduce the goal sensitivity for a 5 sigma detection, with a 5km/s spectral binning of: 209Jy km/s /150 km/s *5 km/s *(1"/21")**2 /5 sigma = 3 mJy For the width of the line (260km/s) and the fact that we want to smooth the spectra to 5km/s, we will be using the coarsest FDM mode for the spw with emissions lines and TDM for the other spw, to maximize continuum sensitivity. We only need to recover spatial scales that can be compared with the other line transitions, which will be more compact, so we have used a conservative estimate of ~5" which does not require additional ACA observations.

CO(2-1) flux derived from CO(1-0) SEST observations (45" resolution) by Wiklind et al (1989), assuming a CO(2-1)/CO(1-0)~1 intensity ratio Using a standard Jy/K for the SEST of 26, the integrated CO(2-1) flux for a 21" beam would be 98 Jy km/s For an angular resolution of 1", we deduce the goal sensitivity for a 5 sigma detection, with a 10km/s spectral binning of: 98Jy km/s /280 km/s *10 km/s *(1"/21")**2 /5 sigma = 1.6 mJy For the width of the line (280km/s) and the fact that we want to smooth the spectra to 10km/s, we will be using the coarsest FDM mode for the spw with emissions lines and TDM for the other spw, to maximize continuum sensitivity. One of the spw is set to detect CS(5-4). We only need to recover spatial scales that can be compared with the other line transitions, which will be more compact, so we have used a conservative estimate of ~10" which does not require additional ACA observations.

CO(3-2) flux derived from SEST CO(2-1) observations (21" resolution) by Wiklind et al (1989), assuming a CO(3-2)/CO(2-1)~0.8 intensity ratio. Using a standard Jy/K for SEST of 26, the integrated CO(3-2) flux for a 21" beam would be 176 Jy km/s For an angular resolution of 1", we deduce the goal sensitivity for a 5 sigma detection, with a 10km/s spectral binning of: 176Jy km/s /280 km/s *10 km/s *(1"/21")**2 /5 sigma = 3 mJy For the width of the line (280km/s) and the fact that we want to smooth the spectra to 10km/s, we will be using the coarsest FDM mode for the spw with emissions lines and TDM for the other spw, to maximize continuum sensitivity. We only need to recover spatial scales that can be compared with the other line transitions, which will be more compact, so we have used a conservative estimate of ~7" which does not require additional ACA observations.

CO(4-3) flux derived from CO(2-1) SEST observations (21" resolution) by Wiklind et al (1989), assuming a CO(4-3)/CO(2-1)~0.5 intensity ratio. Using a standard Jy/K for SEST of 26, the integrated CO(4-3) flux for a 21" beam would be 196 Jy km/s For an angular resolution of 1", we deduce the goal sensitivity for a 5 sigma detection, with a 10km/s spectral binning of: 196Jy km/s /280 km/s *10 km/s *(1"/21")**2 /5 sigma = 3 mJy For the width of the line (280km/s) and the fact that we want to smooth the spectra to 10km/s, we will be using the coarsest FDM mode for the spw with emissions lines and TDM for the other spw, to maximize continuum sensitivity. We only need to recover spatial scales that can be compared with the other line transitions, which will be more compact, so we have used a conservative estimate of ~5" which does not require additional ACA observations.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose observations of the CO transitions J=2-1,3-2,4-3 of the central regions of a sample of 9 bonafide Seyferts (types 1 and 2) and low nuclear luminosity Seyfert-like spirals. These observations will be used to model the physical conditions of the molecular gas in the central regions of these Active Nuclei, using a single tracer sampled at scales of ~100pc on the host galaxies. The use of a single tracer will significantly simplify the analysis and will also allow the comparison of the inferred molecular gas state with that derived with other tracers/species. The obaservations will also allow modelling of gas infall. The sample has been selected so that it covers a wide range of nuclear bolometruc luiminosities and includes both types 1 and 2. Our results on the physical conditions of the gas, and its structure, will be used to study possible trends of these parameters with bolometric nuclear luminosity and nuclear activity type (1 or 2). Discovering the presence of a trend (or its lack thereof) along the luminosity and/or activity type classification axes will have very important implications for our understanding of the Seyfert activity phenomenon

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: University College London, London, University of
ALMA Project Office, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
IRAM Grenoble, Institute of Millimetric Radioastronomy (IRAM)
